metadata.title: Effects of sputtering conditions on the activities of high-performance CO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> methanation catalysts prepared by a co-sputtering technique using the polygonal barrel system

Graphical abstract This study investigated the effects of sputtering conditions on the activities of high-performance CO2 methanation catalysts prepared by a co-sputtering technique, employing a polygonal barrel apparatus. Average size of smaller Ru nanoparticles generated by co-sputtering Ru with TiO2 or ZrO2 varied with changes in the area ratio of the sputtering targets. The reaction temperature was decreased with decreases in the Ru particle size, and the most effective target area ratio was Ru:ZrO2 = 1:0.5 when co-sputtering Ru and ZrO2. For this optimized catalyst, increasing the sputtering time did not affect the Ru particle size but improved the catalytic activity. Small Ru particles were maintained even at a reaction temperature of 360 °C, indicating that undesirable decreases in catalytic activity due to particle growth can be suppressed using this co-sputtering technique. These highly active co-sputtered catalysts would have applications in systems intended for the reduction of CO2 emissions. Keywords CO2methanation catalysts Ru-metal oxide co-sputtering Ru particle size Sputtering conditions Polygonal barrel-sputtering method Dry process 1 Introduction Increasing CO2 emissions are a significant environmental issue worldwide because CO2 is a primary factor in global warming. Therefore, technologies to decrease CO2 emissions such as CO2 capture and storage (CCS) [1,2] have been widely investigated. However, these processes are not cost-effective at present and are subject to considerable safety restrictions. Partly for this reason, the concept of CO2 capture and utilization (CCU) has recently attracted considerable attention. In this process, beneficial products are synthesized using CO2 that has been previously collected as a feedstock [3,4], thus recycling CO2 while reducing CO2 emissions. The CO2 methanation reaction (CO2 + 4H2 → CH4 + 2H2O) is one possible CCU technology [3–12]. This reaction produces natural gas (that is, methane) used for fuels from CO2, is cost-effective and has fewer operational restrictions compared with CCS technologies. Based on these benefits, the practical applications of CO2 methanation have been extensively researched, such as in the case of so-called “Power to Gas” systems [8–12]. Unfortunately, these systems have typically been operated over 300 °C at present, although the reaction temperature of CO2 methanation depends on the used catalysts and the conditions [11,12]. This high-temperature operation is due to the relatively low activities of catalysts at low temperatures, which leads to additional CO2 emissions. On the other hand, our group previously developed an original particle surface modification system, termed the “polygonal barrel-sputtering method” [13–16]. In this method, sputtering is conducted without heating, by which the particle growth of deposited materials such as metals and metal alloys is suppressed unlike conventional wet processes [14]. In addition, during the sputtering, a polygonal barrel including particle supports is rotated or oscillated to fragment the secondary particles of supports into the primary particles and stir them. As a result, small nanoparticles can be highly dispersed on the surfaces of supports, leading to the high catalytic activities in various reactions [14–16]. Thus, we investigated the preparation of highly active CO2 methanation catalysts using the polygonal barrel-sputtering method [17,18]. For TiO2-supported Ru (Ru/TiO2) catalysts prepared by our sputtering method, the methane was obtained at a high yield even at less than 200 °C, and the reaction temperature of CO2 methanation was successfully decreased by over 200 °C, as compared with that for the Ru/TiO2 catalysts prepared by the wet processes [17]. In addition, the catalytic activity of this new material could be increased by decreasing the Ru particle size below 5 nm [17], and so this catalyst evidently expresses structure sensitivity [19–21]. It has been reported that the sizes of deposited metal particles can be reduced using a co-sputtering technique [22,23]. This phenomenon is probably attributed to an effect that co-sputtered materials interrupt the cohesion of sputtered small metal clusters to lead the particle growth on supports [24]. Based on these reports and the structure sensitivity of our catalytic system, we attempted to prepare CO2 methanation catalysts by the co-sputtering of Ru with various metal oxides (TiO2 or ZrO2) to further improve the catalytic activity [25]. The results showed that the resulting co-sputtered materials lowered the reaction temperature of CO2 methanation relative to that using Ru-sputtered samples [25]. However, the effects of sputtering conditions on the catalytic activities of these co-sputtered catalysts remain uncertain. Thus, in the present study, we investigated the effects of the area ratios of sputtering target plates and the sputtering time on catalytic activities, with the aim of obtaining more highly active CO2 methanation catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of samples Samples were prepared using the polygonal barrel-sputtering system shown in Fig. 1 (A). TiO2 particles having an anatase structure (ST-41, particle size: 300 nm, Ishihara Sangyo Kaisha, Ltd. or TAF-520 J, particle size: 100 nm, Fuji Titanium Industry Co., Ltd.) were used as the supports, because our preliminary experiment indicated that Ru catalysts prepared using the anatase TiO2 supports had the higher CO2 methanation activity than those using other supports such as rutile TiO2. Prior to use, these TiO2 supports were heated at 180 °C to reduce aggregation due to the presence of water. Plates composed of Ru (99.9% purity) and metal oxides (TiO2: 99.99% purity or ZrO2: 99.9% purity) (size: 25 × 100 mm, Toshima Manufacturing) were simultaneously used as the co-sputtering targets. The ratio of the exposed area of the Ru plate to that of the metal oxide plate was varied between 1:0.5, 1:1, and 0.5:1 using a stainless steel plate as a mask (see Fig. 1(B)). In each sample preparation process [17,25], a 3 g portion of TiO2 particles was introduced into an octagonal barrel, and this barrel was installed in the vacuum chamber. After the chamber was slowly evacuated by rotary and oil diffusion pumps to a pressure of 8 × 10-4 Pa or less, Ar gas (99.9999% purity) was carefully introduced into the chamber. Sputtering was then performed without heating at an Ar gas pressure of 0.8 Pa by supplying 100 W of AC power to a radio frequency (RF) power generator (frequency: 13.56 MHz ±5 kHz). During sputtering, the octagonal barrel was oscillated at intervals of 12 s with an amplitude of ± 75° to fragment the secondary particles of TiO2 into primary particles while also stirring the particles. After sputtering, N2 gas (99.99% purity) was gradually introduced to return to atmospheric pressure, following which the prepared samples could be extracted. The samples prepared by the co-sputtering of Ru and TiO2 and of Ru and ZrO2 are denoted herein as Ru-TiO2/TiO2 and Ru-ZrO2/TiO2, respectively. A Ru/TiO2 sample was also prepared using a Ru target plate (99.9% purity, size: 50 × 100 mm, Toshima Manufacturing) for reference purposes. Sputtering of this target was conducted at an AC power of 100 W, an Ar gas pressure of 0.8 Pa, and using a sputtering time of 2 h, with ST-41 as the TiO2 support. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The amount of Ru deposited on each sample was determined from X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF: PW2300, Philips) using a Rh X-ray tube operating at 50 mA and 60 kV and a calibration curve constructed based on analyses of Ru powder (Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo) [25]. The morphology of the deposited Ru was assessed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM: JEM-2100, JEOL) at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The size distributions of the Ru particles were obtained by directly measuring the sizes of more than 100 randomly chosen particles in magnified TEM images. 2.3 Catalysis The catalytic activity of each specimen was evaluated [25]. In these trials, CO2 methanation was carried out in a conventional fixed bed flow reactor made from a 20 mm diameter glass tube, at atmospheric pressure. A 1.0 g quantity of catalyst mixed with 2.0 g of glass fiber was introduced in the reactor to obtain a cylindrical catalyst layer 30 mm in depth. The catalyst was neither preheated nor preactivated. The catalytic reaction was subsequently performed by feeding a mixture of pure gaseous CO2 (10 mL/min) and H2 (40 L/min) through the tube, both of which were controlled by mass flow controllers. These conditions gave a CO2:H2 molar ratio of 1:4. During the reaction, the reactor was heated in a furnace and the reaction temperature was monitored at the top, middle, and bottom of the catalyst bed using three thermocouples. The effluent gases were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC: GC-2014, Shimadzu), employing a thermal conductivity detector and a Shincarbon-ST column (Shinwa Chemical Industries) with Ar as the carrier gas. The methane yield was determined from the GC data according to the equation: (moles of CH4 formed)/(moles of unreacted CO2 + moles of CH4 formed) × 100. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of the target area ratio Ru-TiO2/TiO2 and Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 specimens were prepared using various area ratios between the Ru and metal oxide targets in conjunction with ST-41 as the TiO2 support. The associated sputtering conditions and the resulting Ru deposition amounts of these co-sputtered samples and Ru/TiO2 are provided in Table 1 . When producing Ru/TiO2, Ru was deposited at a level of 5.7 wt.% after sputtering for 2 h. To deposit a similar loading of Ru, the sputtering time was adjusted based on the target area ratio (using 4 h for ratios (Ru:metal oxide) of 1:1 and 1:0.5, and 8 h for a ratio of 0.5:1). As a result, the Ru deposition amounts were in the range of approximately 4–7 wt.%, meaning that similar amounts of Ru were deposited on all the Ru-TiO2/TiO2 and Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 samples. It is noted that in our previous studies on the preparation of Pt-Ru alloy catalysts by a co-sputtering technique, the atomic ratios of Pt and Ru were well controlled by adjusting the target area ratios [14,26]. This trend was achieved by controlling the ratios of the sputtering rates, implying that the deposition amounts of Ru and TiO2 or ZrO2 would also be directly linked to the target area ratios. Fig. 2 (A) shows typical TEM images and size distributions of the Ru deposited on the Ru-TiO2/TiO2. Highly dispersed Ru nanoparticles (seen as black dots) are evident on the gray TiO2 particles using as the support material. The particles were all less than 4 nm in size for all samples and the average sizes were estimated to be 1.9, 1.7, and 2.1 nm for Ru:TiO2 area ratios of 1:0.5, 1:1, and 0.5:1, respectively. Fig. 2(B) presents the results obtained for the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2. Similar to the Ru-TiO2/TiO2, Ru nanoparticles with sizes below 4 nm were highly dispersed on the TiO2 support. The average sizes for the samples prepared at Ru:ZrO2 area ratios of 1:0.5, 1:1, and 0.5:1 were 1.3, 1.8, and 1.7 nm, respectively. It should be noted that the average particle sizes in all specimens were decreased by factors of approximately 0.5–0.8 relative to the sizes of Ru particles in the Ru/TiO2, as shown in Fig. 2(C) (average size: 2.5 nm, distribution: 1.1–5.2 nm). This result confirms that the co-sputtering technique reduced the Ru particle sizes. Subsequently, the CO2 methanation reaction was conducted using the Ru-TiO2/TiO2 and Ru-ZrO2/TiO2. In these measurements, the highest temperatures tended to be obtained at the top of catalyst bed, and these values were represented as the reaction temperatures. Fig. 3 (A) summarizes the results obtained with the Ru-TiO2/TiO2 samples. Using the material generated with a Ru:TiO2 area ratio of 0.5:1, the CH4 yield was 12.7% at 160 °C and this yield was gradually increased to 87.8% with increases in the reaction temperature to 260 °C, reaching 91.7% at 300 °C. The material generated at a target ratio of 1:0.5 produced a similar trend, however the reaction progressed at lower temperatures compared with the 0.5:1 material. Using a Ru:TiO2 area ratio of 1:1, the reaction temperature was further decreased and a CH4 yield over 260 °C was increased to around 90 %. Thus, a Ru:TiO2 area ratio of 1:1 was optimal for the preparation of high-performance Ru-TiO2/TiO2 catalysts. The results obtained using the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 are summarized in Fig. 3(B). With these samples, the CH4 yield was also increased as the temperature was raised. In the case of a Ru:ZrO2 area ratio of 1:1, the CH4 yield of 16.0% at 160 °C was increased to 91.4% at 260 °C and this value was almost unchanged between 280 and 300 °C. At Ru:ZrO2 = 0.5:1, higher CH4 yields than those produced by the 1:1 material were observed between 160 and 240 °C, indicating that the reaction temperature was decreased. The 1:0.5 specimen showed a further shift to lower reaction temperatures. Thus, the highest performing Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 catalyst was obtained at a target area ratio of 1:0.5. Fig. 3(C) presents a comparison of the catalytic activities of the highest performing co-sputtered samples (Ru-TiO2/TiO2 with Ru:TiO2 = 1:1 and Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 with Ru:ZrO2 = 1:0.5) to that of the Ru/TiO2. The reaction temperature when using the Ru-TiO2/TiO2 was approximately 20 °C lower than that for the Ru/TiO2, while the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 showed a further temperature decrease of close to 10 °C as compared with the Ru-TiO2/TiO2. Therefore, the most highly active catalyst was synthesized using Ru and ZrO2 targets with an area ratio of 1:0.5. This material lowered the reaction temperature by approximately 30 °C relative to that on the Ru/TiO2. It is emphasized that the specific activity values at 200 °C were 3.16 μmolch4 gcat. −1 s−1 for Ru/TiO2, 4.41 μmolch4 gcat. −1 s−1 for Ru-TiO2/TiO2, and 4.94 μmolch4 gcat. −1 s−1 for Ru-ZrO2/TiO2. These values were higher than those of Ru catalysts prepared by the wet processes using pure anatase, pure rutile, and commercial TiO2 (∼2.57 μmolch4 gcat. −1 s−1) [27], and mesoporous TiO2 (0.86–2.05 μmolch4 gcat. −1 s−1) [28] as the supports. Thus, the polygonal barrel-sputtering method is useful for preparing the highly active CO2 methanation catalysts. Fig. 4 plots the temperatures to reach 50% CH4 yields (as extrapolated from Figs. 3(A)–(C)) as functions of the average Ru particle size. The reaction temperature is seen to have gradually decreased with decreases in the Ru particle size. This trend likely reflects the structure sensitivity of these materials [19–21] based on our previous study that the turnover frequency was increased by decreasing the Ru particle size [17]. Although this finding is vital information from a catalytic design perspective, the particle size dependence in Fig. 4 is a contrast to the reported results of Ru catalysts prepared by the wet processes that the activities were improved with the increase in the particle sizes [6,29]. This discrepancy probably indicates that the reaction mechanism of the sputtered catalysts are completely different from those of the traditional catalysts that the CO2 methanation occurs at the interfaces between the Ru particles and the support [6,30–33]. 3.2 Effect of sputtering time The effect of sputtering time on the CO2 methanation activity was evaluated using Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 samples prepared at a Ru:ZrO2 target area ratio of 1:0.5 while varying the sputtering time, using TAF-520 J as the TiO2 support. The amounts of Ru deposited in the specimens produced using sputtering times of 4, 8, and 12 h were 6.4, 17.2, and 23.3 wt.%. Fig. 5 shows plots of the Ru deposition amount as a function of the sputtering time. A linear relationship is evident, confirming that this sputtering method allows the amount of Ru deposited to be controlled by varying the sputtering time. Fig. 6 presents TEM images of various specimens. In each sample, the Ru nanoparticles are seen to have been highly dispersed over the TiO2 particles. The Ru particle sizes were distributed in the ranges of 0.4–2.3 nm (average size: 1.2 nm) for the 4 h sample, 0.4–2.6 nm (1.3 nm) for the 8 h sample, and 0.7–3.0 nm (1.3 nm) for the 12 h sample. These results indicate that the particle size was relatively unaffected by the sputtering time, which agrees with the results from our previous study concerning carbon-supported Pt-Ru alloy catalysts [14]. Fig. 7 provides results from CO2 methanation activity tests using either the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 or the Ru/TiO2 (as a reference). Compared with the Ru/TiO2, the reaction temperatures of the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 samples were greatly decreased regardless of the sputtering time. Using the material produced with a sputtering time of 4 h, the CH4 yield changed from 20.3% to 76.6% between 160 and 200 °C and then gradually increased to 95.3% at 240 °C. These results are similar to those obtained from the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 made using a Ru:ZrO2 area ratio of 1:0.5, as shown in Fig. 3(B). In the case of the samples produced with sputtering times of 8 and 12 h, the reaction temperatures were 20–40 °C lower than that for the 4 h sample, demonstrating that the catalytic activity was improved by increasing the sputtering time. As noted, the amount of Ru deposited was increased along with the sputtering time, whereas similar particle sizes were observed in all the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 samples, as shown in Figs. 5 and 6. Therefore, the Ru surface area was increased as the sputtering time was prolonged, leading to decreases in the reaction temperature. This result possibly implies that the reaction sites of CO2 methanation for our catalysts are the surfaces of Ru nanoparticles. The particle sizes of deposited metals have been shown to increase during the CO2 methanation reaction at higher temperatures, which in turn lowers the catalytic activity [34,35]. To evaluate this phenomenon in the present systems, Ru/TiO2 and Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 samples after use in the methanation reaction at 360 °C were observed by TEM. The resulting image of Ru/TiO2 is presented in Fig. 8 (A), which shows some larger Ru particles. These particle sizes ranged from 1.5 to 25.0 nm, meaning that the size distribution was wider after the reaction (see Fig. 2(C)). The average size (4.3 nm) was also increased by a factor of 1.7 compared with that of the fresh sample. These results demonstrate that particle growth was induced during the reaction at the higher temperature of 360 °C. Figs. 8(B) presents TEM image and size distribution for the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 sample after the reaction (sputtering time: 12 h). The Ru particles in this sample maintained relatively small sizes. The particle sizes ranged from 0.7 to 4.8 nm and the average size was estimated to be 2.1 nm. This result is similar to that of Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 catalyst prepared by sputtering for 4 h reported in our previous study [25], but completely different from the data for the Ru/TiO2. It is evident that particle growth during the reaction at a higher temperature was suppressed after using the co-sputtering technique to prepare the catalysts irrespective of the sputtering time. This result can be attributed to various specific phenomena, such as the barrier effect of metal oxides that avoids contact with the Ru particles. This effect is helpful in terms of maintaining high catalytic activity throughout the CO2 methanation reaction. 4 Conclusions This study evaluated the effects of sputtering conditions when preparing co-sputtered Ru and metal oxide samples with regard to CO2 methanation activity. When using this technique, the Ru particle size was found to be smaller than that in Ru/TiO2 regardless of the area ratio of the targets. The more high-performance catalysts were obtained at target area ratios of Ru:TiO2 = 1:1 for the Ru-TiO2/TiO2 and Ru:ZrO2 = 1:0.5 for the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2. Between these two materials, the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 prepared at 1:0.5 showed the highest activity, such that the reaction temperature was decreased by approximately 30 °C compared with that of Ru/TiO2. It is emphasized that the evident decrease in reaction temperature was attributed to the deposition of smaller Ru nanoparticles. However, this particle size dependence was a contrast to those of the catalysts prepared by the wet processes reported in literatures, suggesting that the reaction mechanism of the sputtered catalysts is completely different from those of the traditional catalysts. The effect of sputtering time was investigated by preparing Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 at a Ru:ZrO2 ratio of 1:0.5. Under these conditions, small Ru particles (average size: 1.2–1.3 nm) were deposited on the TiO2 particle surfaces, even though sputtering time was increased from 4 h to 8, and 12 h. The reaction temperature was decreased as the amount of Ru deposited was increased with the sputtering time. This result might imply that the reaction sites for our catalysts are the surfaces of Ru nanoparticles. It should be noted that following the methanation reaction at 360 °C, some Ru nanoparticles in the Ru/TiO2 were enlarged whereas the particles in the Ru-ZrO2/TiO2 sample prepared by sputtering for 12 h maintained relatively small sizes. In addition, the result of this 12-h sample was similar to that of 4-h sample in our previous study. Thus, particle growth can be suppressed by using the co-sputtering technique to prepare the catalysts regardless of the sputtering time. This is likely ascribed to phenomena such as the barrier effect provided by the metal oxides, which prevents contact with the Ru particles. This effect assists in maintaining an effective CO2 methanation reaction. coredata.dc:description: This study investigated the effects of sputtering conditions on the activities of high-performance CO2 methanation catalysts prepared by a co-sputtering technique, employing a polygonal barrel apparatus. Average size of smaller Ru nanoparticles generated by co-sputtering Ru with TiO2 or ZrO2 varied with changes in the area ratio of the sputtering targets. The reaction temperature was decreased with decreases in the Ru particle size, and the most effective target area ratio was Ru:ZrO2 = 1:0.5 when co-sputtering Ru and ZrO2. For this optimized catalyst, increasing the sputtering time did not affect the Ru particle size but improved the catalytic activity. Small Ru particles were maintained even at a reaction temperature of 360 °C, indicating that undesirable decreases in catalytic activity due to particle growth can be suppressed using this co-sputtering technique. These highly active co-sputtered catalysts would have applications in systems intended for the reduction of CO2 emissions.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of sputtering conditions on the activities of high-performance CO2 methanation catalysts prepared by a co-sputtering technique using the polygonal barrel system
